elements.title: Self-Service Flexibility Expression for Day-of-Week Matching
elements.problem: Tyler's primary matching variable is day-of-week flexibility (Saturday-Wednesday ideal, Sunday-Wednesday acceptable, Sunday-Thursday possible). Currently, this flexibility is extracted through a 15-minute phone call where the agent asks probing questions and translates verbal answers into matching parameters. The platform has no mechanism for guests to express and visualize how adjusting their day preferences affects available matches and pricing. Eyal's Action phase (Ch 3) requires minimizing the effort of the intended behavior. A phone call to express 'I'm flexible on days' is the maximum-effort version of an action that should be as easy as toggling day chips.
elements.solution: Design a day-of-week flexibility selector that lets guests: (1) Select their ideal days as the primary configuration. (2) Mark additional days as 'flexible' — meaning they could shift to those days if it improves matching or pricing. (3) See real-time feedback showing how flexibility changes results: 'Your ideal days match 2 listings. Adding Sunday expands to 5 listings.' This makes flexibility visible, valuable, and self-service. The pattern should work like a Hook Model Action: minimal effort (tapping day chips) with immediate reward (seeing more options appear). The agent call revealed that flexibility is the single most important variable for matching success — the agent's exact words were 'That sounds much better because now I have something to work with' (18:13) when Tyler expanded his flexible days.

evidence.quote: I'm a little bit flexible, but it depends. Saturday through Wednesday night is the best for me is ideal, but I'm a little bit flexible depending on the other person's needs.
evidence.insight: Flexibility is conditional and gradual — the guest won't commit to all variations at once. The UI must allow expressing degrees of flexibility, not binary yes/no.

evidence.quote: That sounds much better because now I have something to work with.
evidence.insight: Agent productivity directly correlates with guest flexibility expression. When Tyler offered more flexible days, matching became possible. The platform must replicate this dynamic.

evidence.quote: Companies leverage two basic pulleys of human behavior to increase the likelihood of an action occurring: the ease of performing an action and the psychological motivation to do it.
evidence.insight: Expressing flexibility via phone is high-effort. Tapping day chips with real-time matching feedback is low-effort with high motivation (more options). This is the correct Fogg Model application.

evidence.quote: Six elements of simplicity — the factors that influence a task's difficulty: time, money, physical effort, brain cycles, social deviance, non-routine.
evidence.insight: A phone call scores poorly on time (15 min), brain cycles (verbal articulation of complex preferences), and non-routine (most people don't call strangers). A visual day selector scores well on all six.

elements.user_goal: Express my schedule flexibility quickly and see how it affects my options, without having to explain it verbally to someone.
elements.company_goal: Increase match rates by making guest flexibility visible and actionable, reducing dependency on agent-mediated matching.
elements.time_budget: Under 30 seconds to select ideal days and mark flexible alternatives. Real-time results update within 500ms of each day toggle.
anti_goals: DO NOT require the guest to commit to specific days before showing any results — show results for ideal days first, then show how flexibility expands options.
DO NOT present day selection as a calendar grid for a multi-month lease — use day-of-week chips (Mon, Tue, Wed...) since the pattern repeats weekly.
DO NOT hide the pricing impact of day selection — if weekends cost more, show this immediately, not after a phone call.
DO NOT force the guest to call an agent to explore flexibility — self-service must be the primary path.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of guests who complete a search using the flexibility selector without agent assistance. Target: 60% of new guests can find at least one match within 2 minutes of self-service search.

elements.title: Guest Investment Capture at First Contact
elements.problem: Tyler provided comprehensive requirements during his call (location: Chelsea, days: Sat-Wed, budget: ~$2000, duration: 2+ months, private bathroom, single occupancy, self-cleaning, no parking). All of this data was captured by the agent in the agent's notes — none of it was stored in the platform. Eyal's Investment phase (Ch 5) shows that stored value creates switching costs and loads the next trigger. Tyler has zero stored value on Split Lease. If the agent disappears, Tyler's data disappears. The guest can walk away with zero cost because they've invested nothing in the platform.
elements.solution: Design the first guest interaction to capture and store investment in the platform, not the agent. (1) When a guest responds to a listing (from Craigslist or any channel), immediately create a guest profile that stores their requirements as structured data: preferred location, days, budget, duration, amenities. (2) Show the guest their profile: 'Here's what we know about you so far' — making the stored value visible. (3) Use the stored requirements to pre-fill future searches, proposals, and communications. (4) Send the guest an owned trigger (email, app notification) that references their stored preferences: 'We found 3 spaces in Chelsea that match your Saturday-Wednesday schedule.' This transforms the first contact from a disposable phone call into a platform investment that loads the next hook cycle.

evidence.quote: I guess that gives me all the information I need to start working and getting some good for you.
evidence.insight: The agent says 'I have the information' — but the platform has none. The guest's investment (providing detailed requirements) is stored in the wrong place.

evidence.quote: The investment phase increases the odds that the user will make another pass through the hook cycle in the future. The investment occurs when the user puts something into the product such as time, data, effort, social capital, or money.
evidence.insight: Tyler invested time and data (15-minute call with detailed requirements) but put it into the agent, not the product. The product must be the repository for guest investments.

evidence.quote: Investments users make to improve their experience. These commitments can be leveraged to make the trigger more engaging, the action easier, and the reward more exciting with every pass through the hook cycle.
evidence.insight: Stored preferences should make the next search easier (pre-filled filters), the next trigger more engaging (personalized notifications), and the next reward more exciting (better matches).

evidence.quote: On Craigslist summer, you know, I just clicked search for Chelsea.
evidence.insight: Tyler's Craigslist search history is an investment in Craigslist, not Split Lease. Split Lease must capture equivalent investment data on its own platform.

elements.user_goal: Know that my preferences are saved and being used to find matches for me, without having to repeat myself.
elements.company_goal: Create platform-level switching costs by storing guest investment data that can't be replicated elsewhere, reducing dependency on individual agents.
elements.time_budget: Initial preference capture should take under 2 minutes (equivalent to a quick signup with preference quiz). Subsequent visits should show pre-filled preferences with zero effort.
anti_goals: DO NOT require a full account creation before capturing preferences — capture preferences first, account second.
DO NOT store preferences only in agent CRM tools that the guest cannot access — the guest must see and own their stored data.
DO NOT ask for all preferences at once — use progressive profiling to collect the most important ones first (location, days, budget) and expand later.
DO NOT let the agent be the only entity that benefits from stored preferences — the platform must use them for personalized search, notifications, and matching.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of guests who have a stored preference profile within 24 hours of first contact. Target: 80%. Secondary: return visit rate for guests with stored profiles vs. without (target: 3x higher).

elements.title: Weekly Stay Cycle as Hook Loop
elements.problem: Tyler's use case creates a repeating weekly pattern: arrive Saturday, stay through Wednesday, leave Thursday, repeat. This happens for 2+ months, creating 8+ weekly cycles. Each cycle involves: arrival notification, stay experience, cleaning, departure. The platform currently treats the lease as a single long event rather than a series of discrete stay cycles. Eyal's Hook Model (Ch 1-5) shows that habit formation requires repeated cycles of Trigger → Action → Variable Reward → Investment. The weekly stay cycle IS the hook cycle, but only if the platform captures each iteration. Without platform involvement in each weekly cycle, the guest manages stays via text messages and the platform loses the opportunity for habit formation.
elements.solution: Design the active lease as a series of weekly hook cycles, not a single long-term event. Each week: (1) TRIGGER: Send the guest a notification 24-48 hours before their next stay ('Your Chelsea stay starts Saturday — anything to update?'). This is an owned trigger that becomes internal over time. (2) ACTION: One-tap check-in when arriving. The action must be simpler than texting the host. (3) VARIABLE REWARD: Each stay is slightly different — different host interactions, different neighborhood discoveries, different routines. Surface these variations: 'Your 4th stay in Chelsea! Local tip: new gallery opening on W 24th this week.' (4) INVESTMENT: End-of-stay cleaning photo upload and one-tap micro-review. Each investment improves future stays: accumulated reviews build trust score, cleaning photos build reputation, date adjustment history informs scheduling. This transforms 8+ weeks of lease into 8+ hook cycles, each strengthening the habit.

evidence.quote: At least December and January, possibly more.
evidence.insight: 2+ months of weekly stays = 8+ potential hook cycles. Each cycle is an opportunity to deepen the habit or lose the guest to off-platform management.

evidence.quote: You would be kind of cleaning after yourself for the person, that person would be cleaning for you.
evidence.insight: The cleaning exchange is a weekly ritual — a natural investment point in the hook cycle. Cleaning photos as proof create stored value and load the next trigger (positive host review).

evidence.quote: A behavior that occurs with enough frequency and perceived utility enters the Habit Zone, helping to make it a default behavior.
evidence.insight: Weekly stays are high-frequency (4-5 nights/week for months). If the platform captures each cycle, it enters the Habit Zone. If it doesn't, text messaging becomes the habit instead.

evidence.quote: Owned triggers consume a piece of real-estate in the user's environment. They consistently show up in daily life and it is ultimately up to the user to opt into allowing these triggers to appear.
evidence.insight: Weekly stay notifications are owned triggers that can migrate to internal triggers over time. After 4-5 weeks, the guest should check the app automatically before each stay without needing a push notification.

elements.user_goal: Manage my weekly stays effortlessly, with the platform handling scheduling, communication, and documentation so I can focus on my art gallery project.
elements.company_goal: Transform active leases into habit-forming engagement loops that increase retention, generate review content, and create platform dependency that prevents off-platform management.
elements.time_budget: Under 10 seconds for check-in action. Under 30 seconds for end-of-stay cleaning photo + micro-review. The entire weekly platform interaction should take under 2 minutes total.
anti_goals: DO NOT treat a multi-month lease as a single event with one check-in and one review at the end.
DO NOT require the guest to manually track their stay schedule — the platform should know and remind them.
DO NOT make the weekly interaction feel bureaucratic — it should feel as easy as checking a weather app.
DO NOT compete with text messaging by being slower or more complex — the platform action must be faster than sending a text to the host.
elements.success_metric: Weekly active engagement rate during active lease: percentage of stay weeks where the guest uses the platform for at least one action (check-in, message, date change, review). Target: 70% of weeks. Secondary: percentage of stays with cleaning photos uploaded. Target: 50%.

elements.title: External-to-Internal Trigger Migration Through Owned Touchpoints
elements.problem: Tyler's only trigger for engaging with Split Lease is the agent (Sabot). He found the platform through Craigslist (external trigger via another platform), and his only ongoing touchpoint is the agent's phone call. Eyal's trigger theory (Ch 2) shows that habit-forming products must migrate users from external triggers (ads, agent calls, Craigslist posts) to internal triggers (the guest automatically thinks of Split Lease when they need flexible housing). Tyler has no owned triggers: no app installed, no email subscription, no notifications set up. Without owned triggers, there is no pathway to internal trigger formation.
elements.solution: Design a trigger migration pathway that moves the guest from agent-dependency to platform-dependency: (1) PAID/EARNED → OWNED: When the guest first contacts Split Lease (via Craigslist, agent call, or any channel), immediately establish owned triggers: collect email, suggest app install, enable push notifications. Frame it as value: 'Get instant alerts when Chelsea spaces match your Saturday-Wednesday schedule.' (2) OWNED → INTERNAL: Once in active lease, the weekly stay cycle creates natural internal triggers. The platform should reinforce these: 'You always check in on Saturdays — your space is ready.' Over time, the guest should open the app automatically before each stay without needing a push notification. (3) Measure migration: track what percentage of guest actions are initiated by external triggers (agent outreach) vs. owned triggers (notifications) vs. internal triggers (unprompted app opens). The goal is to shift the ratio from 90% external to 60%+ internal over 8 weeks of active lease.

evidence.quote: On Craigslist, I just clicked search for Chelsea. And then I saw that posting.
evidence.insight: Tyler's trigger was Craigslist (external, earned). Split Lease has no owned trigger established after this 15-minute call.

evidence.quote: Without owned triggers and users' tacit permission to enter their attentional space, it is difficult to cue users frequently enough to change their behavior.
evidence.insight: The call ends with zero owned triggers established. No email, no app, no notification permission. The platform has no way to re-engage Tyler without the agent making another call.

evidence.quote: When a product becomes tightly coupled with a thought, an emotion, or a pre-existing routine, it leverages an internal trigger. Internal triggers manifest automatically in your mind.
evidence.insight: Tyler's pre-existing routine is his weekly commute pattern (California → NYC for art gallery). The platform must couple itself to this routine so that 'packing for NYC' automatically triggers 'check Split Lease app.'

evidence.quote: I'll be most likely be back in city early December.
evidence.insight: There's a multi-week gap between this call and Tyler's arrival. Without owned triggers (email updates, matching notifications), he may forget about Split Lease entirely.

elements.user_goal: Get relevant updates about my housing search without having to initiate contact or wait for someone to call me.
elements.company_goal: Reduce agent dependency by establishing platform-owned touchpoints that scale, and create a pathway to habit formation through trigger migration.
elements.time_budget: Trigger establishment (email capture, app suggestion) should take under 30 seconds during first interaction. Owned triggers (notifications) should arrive within 24 hours of first contact and weekly thereafter.
anti_goals: DO NOT rely solely on the agent as the re-engagement channel — if the agent is busy, the guest falls through the cracks.
DO NOT spam the guest with generic notifications — every trigger must reference their specific preferences (Chelsea, Saturday-Wednesday, ~$2000).
DO NOT wait for the guest to create an account before establishing owned triggers — capture email first, full account later.
DO NOT send notifications that require the guest to call the agent to take action — every trigger must link to a self-service platform action.
elements.success_metric: Trigger migration ratio: percentage of guest platform sessions initiated by owned/internal triggers vs. agent outreach. Week 1 target: 30% owned triggers. Week 8 target: 70% internal triggers. Secondary: email open rate for personalized matching notifications. Target: 40%.

elements.title: Date Exception Handling for Holiday and Travel Variations
elements.problem: Tyler's lease includes predictable weekly patterns (Saturday-Wednesday) but also exceptions: he'll travel 3-4 nights before Christmas, will be in NYC for Christmas and New Year's, and the lease duration is open-ended ('at least December and January, possibly more'). The current system requires the agent to manually coordinate these variations with the host. This is exactly the scenario where the Date Change Tool must shine — but only if exceptions are as easy to manage as regular stays. Eyal's Action principle (Ch 3) applies: if changing a date requires more effort than sending a text to the host, the guest will choose the text.
elements.solution: Design date exception handling as a first-class feature of the weekly stay cycle, not an edge case: (1) During proposal creation, let the guest flag known exceptions upfront: 'I'll be traveling Dec 20-23 and won't need the space those nights.' (2) During active lease, provide a 'this week is different' quick action that lets the guest modify their standard pattern with one tap per variation: skip a night, add an extra night, or swap days. (3) Show the financial impact immediately: 'Skipping Dec 20-23 saves you $X. Your host has been notified.' (4) For open-ended leases, provide a 'continue or end' prompt at each natural breakpoint (end of month) rather than requiring explicit cancellation. This makes exceptions feel like normal adjustments, not complex negotiations.

evidence.quote: I'm going to be traveling for like three or four nights before Christmas, but yeah, I'm going to be in the city for Christmas.
evidence.insight: Holiday exceptions are predictable but require coordination. The platform must capture these during proposal creation, not discovered during active lease.

evidence.quote: At least December and January, possibly more.
evidence.insight: Open-ended duration requires graceful extension/termination. The guest should not have to negotiate a new lease to continue — rolling continuation with easy opt-out.

evidence.quote: Six elements of simplicity: time, money, physical effort, brain cycles, social deviance, non-routine.
evidence.insight: Date exceptions must score well on all simplicity factors: fast (one-tap), no extra cost to manage, no physical effort, low brain cycles (visual calendar), socially acceptable (both parties expect flexibility), and routine-compatible (part of the weekly check-in flow).

evidence.quote: The investment phase isn't about users opening up their wallets and moving on with their day. Rather, the investment implies an action that improves the service for the next go-around.
evidence.insight: Each date exception handled through the platform is an investment: it stores the guest's pattern variations, improves future scheduling predictions, and reinforces platform usage over text-based coordination.

elements.user_goal: Adjust my weekly stay pattern for holidays and travel without complex negotiation or extra effort.
elements.company_goal: Keep date management on-platform to maintain engagement data, prevent off-platform coordination, and ensure billing accuracy for irregular weeks.
elements.time_budget: Under 15 seconds to modify a single week's schedule. Under 30 seconds to flag exceptions during proposal creation.
anti_goals: DO NOT treat exceptions as edge cases that require contacting support — they are normal parts of flexible housing.
DO NOT require the guest to calculate the financial impact of date changes manually — show it instantly.
DO NOT force the guest to re-negotiate the entire lease for a single-week variation.
DO NOT hide the extension option — at the end of each month, proactively ask 'Continue for another month?'
elements.success_metric: Percentage of date exceptions managed through the platform vs. off-platform (text, call). Target: 70% on-platform. Secondary: time to complete a single-week date change. Target: under 15 seconds.
